Unless the player busted, the cards that were not taken remain in play. The next player may choose to play off of those cards or discard them to start fresh.

Some cards will allow you to take specific actions, but those actions are explained on the cards.

And... that's pretty much it.

—description from the publisher

name: Flippin' Birds
description:
Flippin' Birds is a highly addictive game of dexterity and skill. With the simple flick of the finger, try to send each Flippin' Bird into a cup. Time after time, you'll think you have the right flip - only to have the Bird end up a "Dead Duck!" Don't get too concerned with your misses - each Flippin' Bird is worth a certain number of points depending on how they land. Six different Flippin' Birds games are inside - find your favorite and challenge your friends and family for some amazing Bird-Flippin' Fun!

—description from the box

name: Focus
description: The game consists of square cards which have three properties: Shape, color and number. There are four varieties of each property. Taking turns, players flip open a card from their personal pile and put it on the next of four stacks of open cards in the middle of the table. As soon as there are three cards which share one property variety, players have to slam down a hand on the table - the first one who does it gets the three cards. When all cards have been played, who ever won most card is the overall winner.

name: Petty Fiefs
description:
Minor princes pit bands of vassals and fickle mercenaries against one another in a struggle to possess the largest and most valuable tracts of land. Later, the princes build and upgrade castles to secure control of their expanding realms. The player whose weaker prince has the strongest, most valuable fiefdom wins.

Petty Fiefs is a game for the piecepack played in two phases:
Lay of the Land, where players lay out the tiles to make the starting provinces and places the princes and warlord into them;
and Contention, where players fight to gain control of the provinces by moving their princes, placing vassals, bidding for control of the warlord, placing mercenaries etc. and then secure control of their provinces by building and upgrading castles.

The game ends when there are no uncontrolled provinces and players total up the values of the provinces for each of their princes and the player whose lowest scoring prince has the highest score wins.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Action Points, Area Majority / Influence, Area Movement, Auction/Bidding, Memory, Modular Board, Secret Unit Deployment, Tile Placement

name: Mexican Standoff: The Black Scorpion Promo Card
description:
JEFE ESCORPIÓN ALFREDO is the wicked wraith of the infamous bandit JEFE ESCORPIÓN NEGRO appearing in the base game of Mexican Standoff. Due to his unpredictable and testy personality only the bravest dare to enter into an alliance with him.

Instead of shuffling into the deck, put the promo card on the table within easy reach. Before playing the first card of the round the player who was dealt Jefe Escorpión Negro of the base game may replace Jefe Escorpión Negro with Jefe Escorpión Alfredo (the one with the black background).

The promo card has two special features:

- After losing a duel in which the promo card was played as a base card the player may retrieve the promo card and put it back into his hand by discarding one card from his hand. The promo card may not be retrieved if the player has no cards left to discard.
- The player who won the card of Jefe Escorpión Alfredo with a trick, scores 25 bonus points. In case the player who got the card originally cannot keep it by taking a trick, i.e. another player takes it, the original owner of the card gets -25 points.

After each round replace the promo card with the card of Jefe Escorpión Negro of the base game, put the promo card back on the table and reshuffle the deck to start a new round.
categories: American West, Card Game, Expansion for Base-game
mechanics: Hand Management, Ladder Climbing, Push Your Luck, Set Collection, Trick-taking

name: Tjugo vita kossor
description:
Tjugo vita kossor ("Twenty White Cows") or, formally, Fäbodsspelet Tjugo vita kossor ("The Chalet Game of Twenty White Cows")is a fairly simple roll-and-move game wherein the players try to catch as many white cows as possible. There is different ways to go between the start and the goal and on some spots things will happen - delivered in rhymes - that means additional or fewer cows. Artist were famous Swedish designer Bertil Almqvist (he is also probably the designer of the game).

The publication year is an approximation, estimated on biographic, historic and artistic grounds.

name: Eldenia
description:
You are Eldenia's hero and adventurer. They prepare to go on adventure by polishing swords and purchasing items in the village. If you're ready, let's go hunting monsters!

In order to gain more fame, you will compete fiercely with the adventurers you join. Sometimes it helps and sometimes it is a stumbling block. Let's be a stronger warrior and defeat the dragon!

In World of Eldenia, each player starts with level 1 first. As you level up your experience(=Power) by defeating a small monster like a rabbit, you can become a more powerful hero. However, you may lose points because of the injuries you suffer from defeating monsters. Do not forget to treat!

New adventurers and heroes may be needed to play more games. For more fun, Eldenia is a constant adventurer.

—description from the designer Yun Young-jin.
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Hand Management, Set Collection

name: The Dangerous Year: 1973
description:
1973 was possibly the nearest that the world came to World War Three. Just following the U.S. withdrawal from Vietnam, and during the height of the Watergate scandal, the Americans were both war weary and disillusioned. The stock market crash of that year only made the situation worse, and when the Yom Kippur War erupted in October, the Israelis began to prepare thirteen of their nuclear weapons to halt the invading Arab armies! In response, the Soviet Union threatened to intervene, thereby causing the United States to alert its forces worldwide to prepare for a war against Russia. Such a war would have occurred when the United States was the most vulnerable and divided, but, ironically, the Americans would have had a vast reservoir of combat veterans from the Vietnam War to commit to action.

The Dangerous Year: 1973 uses a standard area movement system but includes a deck of 54 event cards that add a chaotic element to the game, such as "Denmark Withdraws from NATO" which prevents units from entering the Denmark space that turn, or "Hotline" which allows a player to prevent his opponent from conducting tactical nuclear attacks for the current game turn, and so forth. Event cards represent the various occurrences that could happen in the midst of a sudden war, and they ensure that this game gives the feeling of World War III. One moment, a U.S. aircraft carrier may be sunk by a Soviet submarine, but the next moment, a Soviet ballistic missile may explode on the launch pad. The randomness of a shuffled deck each game ensures that no two games are the same, and there is no perfect strategy...only a sudden execrable war of the worst variety.

This game uses a very simple combat system that is designed to resolve combat quickly, and includes the full panoply of combat units, armor, mech, infantry, artillery, SAMs, ships, fighters, bombers, et cetera, and not to mention the inveterate threat of tactical nuclear weapons. One thing is for sure, if the players do not trigger Armageddon, casualties will nevertheless be high for both sides.

name: Welcome to the Jungle
description:
In the back alleys, boardrooms, and nightclubs are business men, ladies, and thugs. Everyone wants a piece of the pie and It’s all for the taking if you have the guts to grab it.

In Welcome To The Jungle, you take on the role of a crew leader using cash and resources to take over territories, and become kingpin of the jungle. But beware. Your opponents are furthering claims, and tightening their grasp on territories they already control. Only you can gather the crew, weapons, and abilities to battle them by drafting cards in your time of need. First player to become kingpin of the most territories in the jungle wins, so what are you waiting for?

Will you rise or will you fall? There’s no surprise, we’ve seen it all… in the jungle. Welcome.
______________________________

Welcome to The Jungle is a 2-4 player game, where the goal is to become Kingpin of the majority of territories in The Jungle. Players will do this by gaining resources and money through Gambling, drawing Smash and Grab cards, selling weapons, and winning "Turf Wars".

In a Turf War, players fight each other for territories in control. When a player enters a Turf War they draw 15 cards from the "Crew" deck, choosing 10 they would like to keep. Players can also use Weapons and special ability cards to strengthen their deck. Turf wars are 3 rounds, with the player that wins two out of the three rounds winning the turf, and winning the resources and money from the territory.

There's a lot of ways Welcome to The Jungle can be played so read the Rules and Play section below for more details.

Game summary
- A board game for 2-4 players
- Run time is 30 min per player
- Combination of area control, resource management, card battling, deck building, and gambling bring a unique player experience
- "Street Cred" card leveling up system makes each play through unique
- Each crew character has a backstory which builds on The Jungle lore
- 3 different game modes available to play
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Betting and Bluffing, Open Drafting, Take That

name: Wells (fan expansion for Carcassonne)
description:
This expansion adds wells along roads- which act similarly to pennants in cities.

Approved by carcassonnecentral and carcassonne-forum
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fan Expansion, Medieval

name: Gut Check
description:
Gut Check is the game of truth or care about the quality and cost of health care and the need for transparency for patients to make the best decisions. You’re a patient about to undergo an important medical procedure— increase your odds of getting the best care possible by persuading your opponents to show their hands and reveal the true quality of their services.

But there’s a catch! When your opponents are seeking care, take on the role of a hospital and beat the competing hospitals to the punch by sharing the quality of your best procedures and by setting the cheapest prices. Show your mettle as both a patient and a hospital if you want to thrive in this fast-paced party game!

—description from the publisher

name: In/De duction
description:
A free Print and Play game for 2-4 players. Based on inductive logical reasoning, hidden goals and basic mathematical calculations.
Players take turns placing numbered tokens onto bases. At the end of each round tokens are totaled up. In the Induction version of the game players score points for each of their tokens in a total that other players' hidden rules refer to. In the Deduction version of the game players score points for each of their tokens in a total that their own hidden rule refers to. In Induction players win by scoring a certain number of points, in Deduction they win by forcing other players to score a certain number of points.

name: Matapan:  The Naval Battle for Greece, Mar41
description:
The 27-28 March 1941 Allied and Italian naval operations at 40mis/64kms per hex in 3-hour turns. Ultra (if it works) and the possibility of false Luftwaffe reports of reduced British battleship strength being true put opposing commanders in an historical fog of war decision-making environment. Dummy units included to enhance that.

The 7 Greek destroyers who tried to make it into action (via the Canal of Corinth) have the chance to succeed as well. Older, somewhat slower Italian battleships Caio Duilio and Giulio Cesare may be used/risked by Italian player.

Naval combat simplified as in my other naval battle and campaign games, or the players can choose to resolve that instead using my (also free print-and-play) Naval Action (or any other) naval miniatures rules with the game's pixel-by-pixel crafted individual ship pieces.

Naval forces can be divided among multiple strategic and operational/tactical commanders, as in my Leyte Gulf Naval Chess Game.

—description from the designer
categories: Bluffing, Miniatures, Nautical, Print & Play, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Hexagon Grid, Push Your Luck, Secret Unit Deployment, Simulation

name: Scavenge
description:
Scavenge through a house's glorious garbage. Claim your own back scratcher, metal hat, or grand cheeseburger! But watch out. You might knock over a garbage can and cause a commotion if you are too greedy! When furry critters cause too much noise, they scare easily and leave all their spoils behind. So much for a lucky find!

Scavenge is a family oriented 2-5 player press-your-luck game where you and other raccoons rummage through the rubbish while the game tries to reclaim your tastiest treats. Will you store your loot in your Secret Stash at just the right time? Who will find the 3 mythical cheeseburgers. It's every player against the game. There are no player vs player attack mechanics. Feel the joy when someone finds something great and the angst when you had it all but you pushed your luck one card too far!
mechanics: Hand Management, Memory, Push Your Luck

name: Good Cop, Bear Cop
description:
In this town, there are two types of cops; crooked cops, or bears. And bears aren’t allowed to be cops.

Good Cop, Bear Cop is a hidden-identity social deduction game where each player is a cop trying to do their job, except some of you are doing your job while also being bears.

In Good Cop, Bear Cop, players are assigned a secret role – either a noble, reliable bear, or a not-bear. Not-bears, however, are each competing for their own ends – opportunities to be lazy, to make money, or to do gardening!

—description from the publishers

name: Plumbers
description: At this game the players adopt the role of a plumbers in a city building and they will have their owns and secrets objetives. They´ll need to connect differents locations with the water container but... maybe the other plumbers could be a little bad peolples and they could broke the other pipelines making water go out to the common space and this can be bad for all because... What happen when you be without oxigen?

name: Poser
description:
Poser is a hidden identity card game. It’s group storytelling. It’s a party. It's a nostalgic trip to the Awesome 80s. And it’s totally rad.

Each round, players are dealt a face-down Character card, inspired by an 80s teen clique. All players have the same Character, except the Poser.

Next, a Location card is revealed — like a diner, high school, pool, or arcade — along with a Scene card, a ridiculous situation that sets up a story then asks "What happens next?"

Players take turns continuing the story and asking each other questions, with everyone trying to find the Poser (and the Poser trying to figure out the Character). Most of the time, players are just laughing at the absurdity of it all.

The round ends when:


everyone agrees on the Poser’s identity (everyone but the Poser scores)
or the Poser guesses the Character (only the Poser scores)
or seven minutes pass, and a vote is triggered.


And that's it. Winning scores are based off the number of people playing, but everyone usually keeps playing and laughing well after the game ends.

—description from the designer

name: Robinson Crusoe: Adventures on the Cursed Island – In-Store Event Kit
description:
Robinson Crusoe is a cooperative game about castaways on the stranded island.

The Kit includes 1 unique scenario about time travels, 8 unique player characters (Gamer character!) and 4 sets of custom wooden pieces representing food resource. There is also a poster to advertise your Robinson Crusoe game night.

Contains:


Robinson Crusoe: Adventures on the Cursed Island – Wooden Fish Tokens
categories: Adventure, Expansion for Base-game, Exploration, Fighting, Novel-based
mechanics: Action Queue, Cooperative Game, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Dice Rolling, Storytelling, Worker Placement

name: Kugelhagel
description: Rules for historical miniature wargames covering battles during the 19th century, from the Napoleonic period to the American Civil War. The rules are cards driven and geared towards fast play. The book includes scenarios and army lists.
categories: American Civil War, Book, Napoleonic, Post-Napoleonic, Wargame
mechanics: Card Play Conflict Resolution, Dice Rolling

name: Fabricators
description:
Mankind will not be redeemed by our competition, but by our collaboration. It will come slowly, but it will come in time, as we turn our efforts to creating a world where we can all succeed, a little together at a time.

In Fabricators, you are one of those architects of a better future; working to create efficient manufacturing segments, 3d-printing factories and power plants, allocating resources as you try to make life for your workers worth living, and respect their labour.

Fabricators is a player-versus player low-confrontation card game for up to five players where players manage a small economic engine to try and develop an optimally efficient 3d-printed manufacturing sector in a utopian future. It plays in roughly forty-five minutes, and uses Action Selection and a card economy for players to build with.

name: City in Peril
description:
Flames, floods, biohazards, craters, and evil robots abound everywhere. Will you sit idly by and watch, or will you spring into action? Compete against your friends, rivals, and enemies by navigating the city using 91 unique combinations of powers. Rescue the most civilians and prove that you are the greatest hero in the city! Welcome to City in Peril!

This is a two to four person, free-for-all tactical navigation game. It plays in about 30-60 minutes regardless of the number of players. Each player controls a hero, and the goal of the game is to rescue the most civilians. There are 100 civilians that spawn throughout the game at an increasing rate. Players repeatedly navigate their hero from their corner of the city to the opposite corner using abilities from a common power pool.

The board is a top-down view of a city. There is a 6 by 6 grid of street intersections that have one of five obstacles. Civilians appear at these intersections by dice rolls, but the heroes must use power cards to get to them. Each turn, a player chooses one of five pairs of power cards. After their turn is over, the abilities are discarded and replaced by a new pair of cards. Game-play continues until all the civilians are saved.

Each player has a unique starting corner of the board and must move forward towards the opposite corner. Although there is a common pool of powers available to all players, what is useful to one player might not be useful to another. Players who are too greedy to rescue a lot of civilians in a single turn, might find themselves poorly positioned for future turns.

—description from the publisher

name: Cape May Lighthouse
description:
Cape May Lighthouse is a dice-rolling game simulating a vacation in Victorian Cape May, New Jersey.

Players take turns trying to roll symbols to engage in various activities the shore town has to offer: Visiting the lighthouse, going fishing or crabbing, taking a whale-watching cruise, enjoying freshly-caught lobster, and searching the beach for Cape May Diamonds. All of these earn you points. But the sea gulls can spoil your day! Avoid them at all costs or you lose all your points. The first player to reach 1000 points wins the game!

Cape May Lighthouse has a press your luck feature where the next roll could be an encounter with a sea gull.

-description from publisher
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Paper-and-Pencil, Push Your Luck

name: Masters of Gettown
description:
In a world where humanity has fled from a dying solar system and colonised an alien planet, there is only one fast way to untold fame and riches. Each year, the mega city of Gettown plays host to a gladiatorial arena match like no other... 'The Tournament'. Combatants with powerful abilities and high tech weaponry, fight to the death to win wealth, fame and, the ultimate position of Master of Gettown.

Masters of Gettown is the world's first 'full contact dice' battling game. To that end, each game sees all players throwing combat dice in to a three dimensional acrylic arena, trying to end with the highest combat score each turn to either deal damage or defend themselves. During the game, players are encouraged to throw their dice at their own or other player's dice in order to physically change their value as well as activate character or combat abilities via the custom 'ability' die.

With this new 'full contact dice' combat mechanic, interchangeable arena bases (covered in various effect areas to aim for and avoid), a plethora of different characters and futuristic weaponry to equip them with, no two games will ever be the same. Also, with the inclusion of both easy to learn 'beginner' rules as well as 'experienced' rules, players can quickly get to grips with the practice of throwing their dice at other dice and then move on to advanced aspects of the game like bidding hit points and equipment drafting.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Betting and Bluffing, Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Player Elimination, Variable Player Powers

name: Schlaukopf: Das clevere Denkspiel
description:
Find as many words as possible with given letters within 1 minute. The longer the words, the higher the points. The letters are determined with the innovative wheel of letters. After every round the number of usable letters is reduced.

All players are playing at the same time. Who has scored the most points after 5 rounds, is the winner.

—description from the publisher (translated, abbreviated

Ziel des Spiel: notiere aus vorgegebenen Buchstaben (z. B. E, T, N, W, Y, Z) innerhalb 1 Minute so viele Wörter wie möglich (z. B. Ente, Tee, wenn ...).

Je länger die Wörter, desto höher die Punktzahl. Die Buchstaben werden an Hand der Drehscheibe ermittelt. Nach jeder Runde reduziert sich die Anzahl der möglichen Buchstaben.

Alle Teilnehmer spielen zeitgleich gegeneinander. Sieger ist der Spieler, der nach 5 Runden die meisten Punkte erzielt hat.
—description from the publisher

name: Faerie Dice
description:
The Faerie Dice series evolved thematically from the board game Faeries in which the Faeries, aided by Trolls, throw Cheese at each other while racing for safety. The Faerie Dice series of games use only dice-rolling; with players scoring over several rounds. Six is suggested as an ideal maximum number of players, though more could play, with rounds and games taking longer.

Faerie Dice, the first of the series, comprises six unique dice each bearing three Faeries, two Trolls, and one Cheese, which can be used to play two games. The first, Faerie Dice, is a jeopardy game where players choose to collect Faeries, Trolls or Cheese, each scoring differently. Players may continue to roll so long as they continue to score but must be aware of the danger of wiping out their original score or even ending up with a negative score. The second game, The Cheese Cupboard, has players attempting to collect, over four rolls, specific scoring combinations of dice, called for example Bring on the Cheese, Grumpy Trolls, A Light Lunch or the eponymous Cheese Cupboard. As with the first game, scores are totalled over several rounds, with the winner the highest scorer after either a fixed number of rounds or after a set score has been reached by at least one player.

—description from the publisher

name: Faerie Dice 2: Invasion of the Pixies
description:
The Faerie Dice series evolved thematically from the board game Faeries in which Faeries, aided by Trolls, throw Cheese at each other while racing for safety. The Faerie Dice series of games use only dice-rolling; with players scoring over several rounds. Six is suggested as an ideal maximum number of players, though more could play, with rounds and games taking longer.

Faerie Dice 2 Invasion of the Pixies comprises six unique dice each with a Faerie, a Cheese, and one of each of four clans of meddlesome Pixies who try to steal the Cheese from the Faeries. As with Faerie Dice there are rules to two games. Plundering Pixies is a jeopardy game where players try to aid Pixies in capturing Cheese, but must deduct points for combinations of dice lacking Cheese or Pixies or including Faeries. In the second, Thieves and Traitors, players try to roll the highest scores possible over up to three rolls each turn, with varying combinations of Thieving Pixies, a Traitor Pixie, Cheese and Faeries. In both games, scores are totalled over several rounds, with the winner the highest scorer after either a fixed number of rounds or after a set score has been reached by at least one player.

—description from the publisher

name: Bottom: The Card Game
description:
Bottom is a fast moving card game for 2 to 6 players, based on the UK comedy series of the same name starring Rik Mayall and Adrian Edmondson.

Players will take it in turns to draw a card, or play a card, trying to acquire Fiendish Scheme cards.
Once a player has possession of these cards they will soon discover that keeping hold of them is a different challenge as their opponents steal, and fight, to gain the advantage.

This is a free Print and Play game. All of the necessary files can be found in the files section below.

THIS GAME (AND RULES BOOKLET) CONTAINS EXPLICIT LANGUAGE AND CONTENT UNSUITABLE FOR PEOPLE UNDER THE AGE OF 18.

Bottom is a copyrighted property. This is an unauthorized, unofficial game produced merely for the entertainment of fans and is non-profit making.

—description from the publisher
categories: Card Game, Mature / Adult, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Print & Play

name: Curling Dice!: Little Garden
description: Curling Dice!: Little Garden is a dexterity game for 2 to 5 players. Players take turns flicking a dice onto the board; some places that the dice land may cause those dice to score later or may trigger additional actions in a round that follows. Several rounds are played with a scoring taking place between each round.

name: Curling Dice!: Panic Bridge
description: Curling Dice!: Panic Bridge is a dexterity game for 2 to 5 players. Players take turns flicking a dice onto the board; some places that the dice land may cause those dice to score later or may trigger additional actions in a round that follows. Several rounds are played with a scoring taking place between each round.

name: Napoleon and his Marshals: The Dice Game
description:
Napoleon and his Marshals - The Dice Game is a fast playing wargame covering several years of Napoleonic warfare. The game includes two scenarios, one for two player and one for multiplayer.

The game uses a map divided into areas and dice for the counters. The strength is represented by the number of pips. These pips determine the number of dice that can be rolled in combat as well.

Each country represented in the game is handicapped so the game can be ended at any point and determine the final score. The game is designed to introduce new players to Napoleonic games or for experienced players to get a quick game in.

—description from the publisher

name: Shieldwall
description:
Shieldwall aims to recreate the atmosphere of Dark Age battles in the British Isles and Northern Europe. The rules were inspired by Andy Callan's Dark Age Infantry Slog. They adapt the basic Comitatus mechanisms to provide interest and colour to what otherwise might be a fairly boring game of two more or less identically armed shieldwalls crashing into each other.

If you like Vikings and Saxons this could be the game for you!
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Simulation

name: One-Minute Washita River: Custer faces defeat and disaster in 1868
description:
The battle of the Washita River in 1868 is one of the most confusing and misunderstood engagements in the history of the United States military.

George Armstrong Custer led the 7th Cavalry in a dawn attack on what he thought was a single tribal village. It was discovered that Custer had struck one of several Native American camps along the river; now the Gallant Seventh faced hundreds of Arapaho, Kiowa, and Cheyenne warriors. Custer barely avoided encirclement as the Indians moved forward in an attempt to defeat the soldiers and complete the disaster by seizing the regiment's supply column.

One-Minute Washita River is a microgame attempting to portray the battle with a small map and a limited number of counters. This game is a solitaire challenge. The entire battle can be completed in a minute or two.

The player represents the tribal leaders. Groups of Native American fighting men pour out of their villages to block the advance of the cavalry. Rules cover historical elements like the protection (or possible rescue) of tribal noncombatants, the importance of "counting coup" within the tribal military structure, and the danger of reckless action in the face of an unpredictable enemy. Victory is determined by the safety of the noncombatants, the losses suffered by the Indians, and the damage inflicted on Custer's regiment. The playing pieces for the 7th Cavalry represent units the size of a battalion or a company. The supply column is also depicted. The maneuvers of these army formations are controlled by the game system.

This is a companion title in the previously released One-Minute game series that included Waterloo, the Little Bighorn, and the 1967 campaign of Che Guevara in Bolivia. It is a free Print & Play game with a single 8.5" x 11" map, charts, rules, and about two dozen playing pieces or markers.
categories: American Indian Wars, American West, Wargame

name: Bolt Action: Campaign – The Road to Berlin
description:
As the Allies advance towards Germany, they face dogged resistance from the hard-pressed German forces. Take command of the Allies in their final push to end the war in Europe, or hold fast as the German defenders as the fight is brought to your door. This new Campaign Book for Bolt Action offers new linked scenarios, rules, troop types and Theatre Selectors, and provides plenty of options for novice and veteran players alike.

Campaign Overview

Operation Bargration
- Fighting Bargration - Which includes scenarios, special rules and historical context
- Bargration Theatre Selectors - Which includes famous platoons such as the 53rd Guards tank Brigade, German Heavy Tank Abteilung and the 5th Panzer Division!
- Additional German Units:
-- Scenario 1: The Tigers of Krupki
-- Scenario 2: The battle of Pleshchenitsy
-- Scenario 3: The '34'

Lvov-Sandomierz Offensive
- Fighting the Lvov-Sandomierz offensive - Which includes scenarios, special rules and Lvov-Sandomierz specific scenarios
- Lvov-Sandomierz theatre selectors
- Scenario 4: big game hunting - Which includes a hero of the Soviet Union, Lt. Aleksandr P. Oskin

The Warsaw Uprising
- Fighting the Warsaw uprising - Which includes scenarios, special rules and Warsaw uprising specific scenarios
- Warsaw uprising theatre selectors
- Armia krajowa theatre selector - Which includes additional Armia Krajowa Units and German Warsaw Uprising Units
- Scenario 5: Man the barricades
- Scenario 6: Kubus and the grey wolf

The Struggle Continues
- Fighting ‘the struggle continues’ - Which includes scenarios, special rules for ghost wars and the Struggle Continues Theatre Selectors
- NKVD Theatre Selector
- NKVD Additional Units

Clearing The Flanks
- Scenario 7: Breakout from Petsamo

The Vistula-Oder Offensive
- Fighting the Vistula-Oder offensive - Which includes General Scenarios and Vistula-Oder Scenarios
- Vistula-Oder offensive theatre selectors
- Scenario 8: ‘the Ivan’s are coming…’
- Scenario 9: race to the Pileca river
- Scenario 10: an unexpected encounter

Operation Berlin
- Fighting Operation Berlin
- Scenarios - Which include General Scenarios and special rules for Operation Berlin Scenarios
- Operation Berlin theatre selectors - Which include the extended Last Levy Theatre Selector and the replacement Panzer Force
- Additional German Units - Which include The German Replacement Army and a hero of the Soviet Union, junior Sergeant Vasily Kharinaevich Khantaev
- Scenario 11: The Seelow heights
- Scenario 12: Tank hunting
- Scenario 13: Berlin: crossing the spree

The Prague Uprising
- Fighting the Prague uprising - Which includes scenarios, general scenarios, Prague specific scenarios and The ROA
- ROA theatre selector
- Additional Units
- Scenario 14: The Prague uprising: enter the ROA

Appendices: Additional Special Rules
- Snow, mud, ice and frostbite
- Dug-in: foxholes, trenches and gun pits
- Minefields
- City fighting
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Action Points, Chit-Pull System, Dice Rolling, Variable Phase Order, Variable Player Powers

name: コロウラ (Koroura)
description:
Play takes place on a 5 x 5 grid and each player has three robot koroura and three dice.
At the beginning of the game each player rolls their three dice and places them in their koroura. The one with the highest initial value becomes the boss. In order to keep track, the die of the opponents color is exchanged. Players then take turns rolling one of their three dice which are placed in the koroura to determine movement options for that turn. The game ends when the opponents boss koroura is “taken”.

—user summary

name: Kampf gegen das Bünzlitum: Comedy-Erweiterung
description:
The first expansion is here!

10 great Swiss comedians have contributed 10 cards for this beauty. Therefore, a hangover of your risible muscles is guaranteed.
Every card comes with a caricature of the comedian that composed the card. Those comedians are:

Dominic Deville
Beat Schlatter
Andreas Thiel
Guy Landolt
Bänz Friedli
Renato Kaiser
Joël von Mutzenbecher
Hamza Raya
Johnny Burn
Julius Siegenthaler

The box contains 28 red and 72 white cards.

—description from the publisher (translated)
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Humor, Mature / Adult, Party Game

name: ATS: Leatherneck III
description:
The third in a three module suite for use with the Advanced Tobruk System, depicting small-unit actions in the Pacific Theater during WWII.

Leatherneck III contains three additional maps, one large overlay and eight more scenarios, and requires ownership of both Leatherneck I and II.

Gamers must also own the ATS System Rules and playaids to make use of these products.

name: Space Swarm: First Contact
description:
First Contact is the first expansion set for Space Swarm and introduces two new fleets for you to play. Use either the ephemeral Wardens and phase through terrain, or slam into your opponents ships as the Republik, blasting your would be foes at point blank range.

Space Swarm is a fast paced game of miniature spaceship combat that sets 2 players against each other in an easy to learn, quick to play tabletop game!

With rules that are designed to be simple and easy to learn, out-shoot, outmaneuver, and outnumber your opponents to secure victory. Use nimble but fragile Frigates, sturdy Cruisers, or powerful but slow Battleships.

Play with just the Expansion Set, or use multiple sets to play even bigger games, the Expansion Set provides you with an exciting expansion to Space Swarm and includes the range ruler, tokens, and 24 un-assembled ship miniatures (12 Republik, 12 Warden) as well as ship stats and new game types for you to play. This game set is made from 3mm MDF and requires the full rules to play.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: Blood & Steel: Mythological Series
description:
Blood & Steel - Mythological Series

The basic game is a 2-player match, although more players are allowed in battle mode. Each player controls a god or mythological character that fights in the arena. The player who manages to drop his opponent’s hit points to zero wins.

Each character card contains icons that represent his/her characteristics. The characteristics represented are: Initiative, Strength, Reflexes, Endurance, Vigor and Hit Points.

How to play Blood & Steel?: The game is fairly simple, and one match can last about 10 or 20 minutes. Each turn is conducted as follows:

1st Choosing your actions: Each player has a basic identical deck of 20 cards: some are meant for movement, some are meant for attack or defense and others for action. Each player has 3 special cards that are character specific: one for attack, one for defense and one for movement. That makes for a total deck of 23 cards per player. Each player chooses three cards for the turn.

2nd Players roll for initiative, to determine who will conduct his actions first for this turn. Each player rolls 1d10 and adds his character’s initiative modifier.

3rd Both players show simultaneously their chosen cards, but he who won the initiative conducts his actions first.
mechanics: Action Queue, Dice Rolling, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Kaiju Crush: Siphon Portal Promo Tile
description:
An interdimensional portal has appeared in a city park! Use this portal's power to move your monster for more destruction.

Wishing you could use another player’s movement in Kaiju Crush? It’s time to put the Siphon Portal Promo Tile into play.

Place the cool-looking Siphon Portal on one of the Parks in Kaiju Crush, and your movement away from the Park can be based on ANY Movement card in play in the game. You don’t swap the card, but you get what you need.

Rules are written on the promo.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fighting, Territory Building

name: Pawperties
description:
Pawperties is a dice rolling strategy game that allows you to play as one of five different cats! Each cat has their own cat tree, with five total unlocks that include three unique abilities, and then two action skills that you can use to turn the tides against your opponents.

Roll the die, buy pawperties, and use your skills to help you gain more treats than your opponents and claw your to victory! Want to slow things down instead of racing to the finish. Some cats specialize in this play-style and would love to help you steal treats from your opponent or even stop their abilities in their tracks! No matter which play-style you prefer, the first to unlock all five tiers of their cat tower wins, so make sure you keep that in mind!

We have pirates, ninjas, a mafia boss, a pacifist, and a casino owner all trying to help you win this fast-paced race to the top! If you enjoy cats, cat themed games, puns, and cute artwork, then this game is absolutely purrrfect for you!

—description from the publisher

name: Talon: A Tarot Card Game
description:
Talon: A Tarot Card Game is a modern tarot trick taking game designed primarily for use with Trionfi Tarot Playing Cards. Each player receives a hand of 12 cards and players bid to become the declarer by stating how few cards they wish to exchange with the talon or kitty. The declarer's side tries to win the majority of card points in tricks.

The three player game is a simplified form of 42 card Tapp Tarock similar to the kind played in Eastern Europe.

The game for four players is a streamlined form of Königrufen in which the declarer has the option of choosing a hidden partner by naming a king.

The five or six player games use 66 or 78 cards and blend elements of early Tapp Tarock with Swiss card games.

Although designed mainly for three to six players; a two player variant, similar to Strohmandeln or Strawman Tarock, is also provided in which players are dealt additional piles of cards in addition to their regular hands.

—description from the designer

name: Arena of the Elders: Starter Set
description:
Arena of the Elders is a competitive strategy battle arena game for 2-8 players set in a fantasy world. Games can last between 30 and 90 minutes.

Players divide themselves into two teams. Each team controls a deck containing four heroes, two towers, and thirty spells. Teams must fight with their heroes, destroy enemy towers, and capture the enemy flag to win the game.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Action Points, Area Majority / Influence, Betting and Bluffing, Cooperative Game, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Team-Based Game

name: Blood Before Richmond: Malvern Hill
description:
Blood Before Richmond is a series of games recreating some of the Seven Days Battles fought between George B. McClellan’s Army of the Potomac and the Confederate Army of Northern Virginia, under its daring new commander, Robert E. Lee. McClellan squandered a numerical advantage by demonstrating what would become a characteristic knack for turning tactical victories into strategic failures. Lee’s ambitious battle plans were hindered by subordinates who seemed incapable of carrying them out - chief among them, oddly, the usually exemplary Stonewall Jackson. If either side had been up to snuff, the war might have been decided in Late June 1861. Tiny Battle Publishing is proud to present the conclusion to this series of quick-playing, medium-complexity games about these fascinating and overlooked battles of the American Civil War.

A modified 2d6 die roll determines which Confederate Divisions activate on a given turn. Divisions that didn’t pull their weight historically are less likely to show up than those that did most of the fighting. It’s a simple, clever, and elegant way to recreate the difficulties Lee had during the Seven Days, and it creates the frustrating and tantalizing possibility that Jackson could do something if he’d only show up.

Flipping a counter over when you take a hit doesn’t capture the feel of bloody infantry collisions or the horrifying impact of artillery fire. The unique “stack of steps” system uses Step Counters stacked beneath the ID Counter to account for brutal attrition and devastating wipe-outs

The fifth and final game in our series brings the last engagement of the Battles of the Seven Days to light, where having lost his chance to envelop the Army of the Potomac, Lee now faced an enemy firmly entrenched atop Malvern Hill.

Contents:
A whopping 176 action-ready counters.
One beautiful 11x17 inch map.
One gritty 12-page full-color grognard-friendly rule book.
Zippered plastic bag perfectly designed to store your steps.
Six sided dice, cutlasses, and Springfields not included.
categories: American Civil War, Civil War, Wargame

name: Motora
description:
The gods of Motora are angry and in their anger, they are devastating the bountiful island and turning it into a desolate land full of nothing but ruins. Players must take control of the tribes living on the island and try to gather the sacred idols necessary to calm the raging deities.

Motora features worker placement, resource management and capture the flag elements, all taking part on a randomly generated board that is different every time you play.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Player Elimination, Worker Placement

name: Joker Go
description:
Joker Go is a Go variant/expansion using a special deck of cards. Each player has an identical deck of 27 cards which show a configuration of Go stones. In the basic game players choose to either play a stone normally or randomly draw and play a Joker Go card. When you play a Joker card, you place the stones shown on the card onto the board in a spot of your choosing. In the advanced variant you either play a stone normally, draw three Joker Go cards or play a Joker Go card.

A Joker Go card can completely change the board state, making a lost group safe or killing an unkillable group. The potential for multiple stones to suddenly appear on the board subverts player's conventional understanding of the game of Go. It forces players to think about shapes in a new way.

The basic game adds a very random element where you are challenged to make do with a random Joker Go card as best you can. They are powerful, but the shapes you need may not be the shapes you draw.

In the advanced variant you have some flexibility as you have a choice of cards you can play. Having a hand of cards also gives you some strategic goals. You can play in a way that will make your hand cards more valuable. Your opponent has to worry that the "odd" moves you are making will set up a devastating Joker Go card down the line.

name: Inside the Cup Golf
description:
Inside the Cup is a simulation of the sport of golf using PGA Tour players and courses.

The development of the game started as a spinoff of the old Avalon Hill Golf game and then blossomed into something all its own. The stats the PGA tour keeps are much more detailed than ever before allowing for players to really show their strengths and weaknesses on golfer cards. Golfers are rated for driving length and accuracy. The cards show the golfers’ ability to hit greens from all distances along with proximity to the hole. Scrambling shots from the sand or around the green are captured as well as putting ability for distance and keeping away from the 3 putt.

Courses are depicted in colorful segments showing the good and the bad places on each hole. As shots are hit they end up in quadrants on the course that show the next club that will need to be used. Stay in the fairway and your next shot should be easier and hold better on the green. Hitting out of the rough or worse can make the shot to the green harder and might not hold up like you like. You don’t want to be too far off the green as those areas could spell danger, while around the green shows safer chip shots or bunkers to hit out of. Some greens even have adjustments that make them easier to hole out or some are more likely to bring out a 3 putt.

Gamers can just let the golfers’ golf or you can have some strategic decisions to make. Should I hit a little less club onto this narrow fairway? Go for it on this par 5? Should I go pin hunting or just play it safe to the middle of the green? Should I putt aggressively or just lag it up there and get off this green?

There are even ways to quick play the game. You can go hole by hole or finish a round with one roll of the dice. ITCG is a fairly fast playing game that can allow a gamer to take his favorite golfers out on some of his favorite courses without leaving his own table.

name: Supervillain: This Galaxy Is Mine! – League of Villains Expansion
description:
Dear Villains! Colleagues and Friends!

You are invited to participate in a fascinating experiment. As you already know, in a Galaxy far, far away, Superheroes have vanished. The local Villains were swift to use this opportunity and started a marvelous mayhem. They aren’t that experienced yet but have already laid hands on the antimatter and erected Secret Facilities on their planets.

Our duty is to enlighten them by setting the poor things on the right path of mutual destruction. Share your experience, teach disastrous tricks to them — and don’t forget to retreat before it gets too hot. As we always do.

Please submit three copies of your signed applications to the galactic cash register. The name of the lucky winner who is about to join the scuffle first will be announced separately!

Setup: Shuffle New Legend with the Domination deck. Deal one Run for Power! card to each player. Put the upper Legendary Villain card face-up. When a Villain draws New Legend card from the Domination deck, replace the Legendary Villain card with the next one.

Each Legendary Villain has a Salutation, Influence, and Superpower. Salutation comes into effect when the Legendary Villain enters the game. The Legendary Villain's Influence is in effect all the time while the respective Legendary Villain card is in play. Finally, each player may address the Legendary Villain for moral and physical support (activate his/her Superpower) by using Run for Power! card.

You may play Supervillain with League of Villains expansion as it is described in it's basic rules. Or... you may use it as an incredible source of new game modes!

League of Villains is the expansion bringing maximum variability to the game. In addition, it raises the replayability manyfold.

—description from the publisher
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Science Fiction
publishers: Moroz Dev Studio, Rightgames RBG SIA

name: Crime Chicky
description:
Crime Chicky is at it again! With her evil minions and wicked stink bomb eggs, she is out to make life difficult for the residents of Center City! It is your job as heroes of the League of Champions to thwart her insidious plots, save innocent bystanders, and capture her and her minions. The greatest Champion will receive the Key to Center City and the accolades of its grateful citizens.

Aim of the Game!
To win, a player must gain the most Victory Points by capturing Crime Chicky and her minions, saving bystanders and foiling plots.

Needed to Play!
The 7 Crime Chicky Dice (4 Basic Blue Dice and 1 Yellow, 1 Red and 1 Black Die), 12 Power Tokens, 1 Center City board with a matching counter, player boards for each player to track victory points, 12 tracking counters.

Playing the Game!
Each round, every player, beginning with the Starting Player, will take turns rolling 4 or more dice. A player must always roll the 4 Basic Blue Dice during their turn but they may roll the additional colored dice if they choose to. A Player may choose the Yellow Die (5 dice in total). If they choose the Red Die they must also roll the Yellow Die (6 dice in total) and if they choose the Black die they must also roll the Yellow and Red Dice (7 dice in total). The Yellow, Red and Black dice can give a player extra bonus Victory Points but they may also cause Crime Chicky and her Evil Minions to do extra dastardly things.

The player rolls all of their chosen dice, setting aside any dice showing Crime Chicky, an Evil Minion or a Stink Bomb Egg. These dice may not be rerolled.

The remaining dice may be rolled up to 2 more times, again setting aside those showing Crime Chicky, a Minion or a Stink Egg.

Once the players have played eight rounds, the game is over.

Scoring!
In a two player game:
The player with the most Victory Points for capturing Evil Minions receives 2 extra Innocent Bystander Victory Points. If there is a tie, no extra Victory Points are awarded.

The player with the most Victory Points for capturing Crime Chicky receives 4 extra Innocent Bystander Victory Points. If there is a tie, no extra Victory Points are awarded.

In a three or four player game:
The player with the most Victory Points for capturing Evil Minions receives 3 extra Innocent Bystander Victory Points. The player with the secondmost Victory Points for capturing Evil Minions receives 2 extra Innocent Bystander Victory Points. If there is a tie for the most or secondmost captures, the tying players receive all extra Victory Points (3 or 2 depending).

The player with the most Victory Points for capturing Crime Chicky receives 5 extra Innocent Bystander Victory Points. The player with the secondmost Victory Points for capturing Crime Chicky receives 3 extra Innocent Bystander Victory Points. If there is a tie for the most or secondmost captures, the tying players receive all extra Victory Points (5 or 3 depending).

In either case, the player with the most Innocent Bystander Victory Points (after totalling up all points) is the winner and receives the Key to the City. If there is a tie the player who has captured Crime Chicky the most times is the winner.

—description from the publisher

name: PlusMinus: The Boardgame
description:
The main principle of this game is a generally known law of magnetism, saying that charged particles of the same signs repel each other and attract the opposite, in other words: plus attracts minus, minus attracts plus, plus repels plus and minus repels minus. Players, using this principle, perform actions with their pawns, aiming to place five of them in a row. The first to achieve this goal wins the game.

This new edition includes a larger board (6 hexagons per side not 5) and a simplification of the rules.

name: University of Tokyo Protests 1968–1969
description: University of Tokyo Protests 1968–1969 is a four-player game of the University of Tokyo protests from June 1968 to January 1969 by using GMT Games' COIN system. Each player plays the role of insurgency ("All-Campus Joint Struggle League" or "Democratic Youth League of Japan and Certain Party") or counterinsurgency ("Police" or "University and Ministry of Education, Science and Culture"), and then the players fight each other in order to achieve each different victory condition.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Area Movement, Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Dice Rolling, Variable Phase Order, Variable Player Powers

name: Go Oink!
description:
Go Oink or moo, or cock-a-doodle-doo. You make the sound of the animal pictured on your card in order to ask other players if they have the animal you are requesting.

If the player has the animal you are requesting, they must give you all of those cards. Otherwise, that player says Go Oink and you take the top card from the draw pile. If you draw the card you asked for, take another turn. Otherwise, play passes to the left. Whenever you have three matching animal cards, place them in a pile in front of you. These cards are safe from other players.

The game ends when any player gets rid of all card in their hands or when the draw pile runs out. The player with the most sets (3 of the same animal) wins

It's like Go Fish, but a little sillier and louder. If you enjoy acting like an animal, you'll go wild over this card game. The cards come in a big pig storage case.

name: Horus Heresy: Sedition's Gate Booster
description: 120 additional cards for the base game.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Science Fiction

name: Dorasure: Yggdrasil
description:
GIANTHOBBY original board game "DORASURE" Enhanced version 8th!

Yggdrasil, a super-technical research institute, can also be said to go one hundred years ahead of the world.
A new character belonging to Yggdrasil will join the adventure.
"DORASURE" is a fully cooperative miniature board game.

This set is a set for "DORASURE" expansion. "DORASURE" main body is necessary for play.
mechanics: Area Movement, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: OrcQuest WarPath: Quests Box – Wings & Claws
description:
Wings and Claws is a new expansion that will enrich the Orcquest universe with new enemies. With the included side Quests, your heroes will be able to measure forces with two daunting monsters that will build up to some intense, epic fights.

Gather at the depths of the sewers, where no living creature or spirit dares to go. Our heroes have heard of the Tarasque, a giant aberration of nature. They almost ask themselves how she got there.

Another epic battle will be waiting for you in the cemetery of Castelray, where you will be facing a very particular kind of greenskin. Brawls between greenskins happen more often than one would think of, and this is not surprising because for orcs fighting is a rewarding experience. And sometimes, to try and convince some of them, you must first challenge them...

—description from the publisher
categories: Adventure, Expansion for Base-game, Exploration, Fantasy, Fighting, Miniatures
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Modular Board, Variable Player Powers

name: Rumini: Kincsesláda
description:
Uniqe tactical card game with three different versions for youngsters and adults!

Your goal in the game is to compile the most valuable collection of treasures in your treasure chest, gaining the most points. You can collect most points if you have a card in your treasure chest, that no one else has, not even the Bank or if you collect many of the same type of cards, and the Bank also has many of them.

The game includes:
5 types of treasure cards, each with 3 categories, slightly different from one another
3 types of markers:
Red marker: you have to throw out cards permanently
Green marker: you give the card to the Bank
Boat marker: you make the card part of your treasure chest

Game overview:
In the beginning of the game the card pile is divided equally between the players. The first player turn their top card face up and put down without looking at it. As soon as the card is shown anyone can put one of their markers on the card. One card can only have one marker. The round is over when all the players showed the defined number of cards (for example 3 players show 4 cards per person in a round). Cards without markers are used again in the last round, the marked cards are placed according to their marking. The game is over when all the cards are played out.

Scoring:
If you have a card that is not in the Bank, but more than one player has it, is worth 1 point per card.
If you have a card that is also can be found in the Bank, the card will be worth as many points as the number of cards in the Bank.
If you have a card that is not in the Bank, and only one player has it, is worth 10 points.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Memory, Pattern Recognition, Pick-up and Deliver, Trading

name: Tanks: Sherman II
description:
The new Sherman tank was the next evolutionary step from the powerful Grant tank. Its large turret allowed it to mount an even more powerful 75mm gun in the turret rather than the hull front, and with thicker armour. Supplied to the British in large numbers the American built Sherman tank would fight through North Africa and Europe till the end of the war.

This pack contains:
1x unassembled Sherman II tank
1x Sherman II tank card
1x Hero card
2x Crew cards
2x Upgrade cards
categories: Collectible Components, Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers
publishers: Battlefront Miniatures Ltd, Gale Force Nine, LLC

name: Nova Aetas: Duel Pack – Renzo vs Diletto
description:
It contains a scenario and rules on how to play Renzo and Diletto, both as enemies and allies, together with the two epic miniatures representing them.

Contents:
1 Renzo miniature
1 Diletto miniature
4 enemy cards
2 tokens
2 missions
categories: Adventure, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Mythology, Renaissance
mechanics: Action Points, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Modular Board, Role Playing, Storytelling, Team-Based Game, Turn Order: Time Track, Variable Player Powers

name: シープマッチ (Sheep Match)
description:
A bunch of cards have all kinds of different sheep on them. On your turn you draw one card at random from the player to your right and then play as many sheep cards as you want, telling a story to connect them as you go along. Then the other players vote on whether the story made sense or not; if at least half say yes, you can just discard the cards, otherwise you have to draw to replace them.

The goal is to get rid of all your cards. However, the game continues until one team wins. The only catch is, nobody knows what team they're on until they run out of cards! Cards that tell you what team you're on are dealt at the start of the game but are kept face-down and unchecked until you run out of cards. This keeps voting honest even as the game goes on.

While the rules are in Japanese, the cards have no text, so the game can be played in any language.

-- user summary
mechanics: Hand Management, Storytelling, Team-Based Game, Voting

name: Northern Battle, Sekigahara 1600
description:
Northern Battle, Sekigahara 1600 is a two-player wargame of the Siege of Hasedō, the Uesugi clan's attack of the Mogami clan during the Sekigahara Campaign (September 1600 - Keicho 5).
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Siege_of_Hased%C5%8D

This work is designed by Mr. Ryutora Yoshikawa, the designer of "Kawagoe Battle" published in Command Magazine No. 104. The battlefield changes completely when the defeat of the Western Army on the main battle was knowned. It requires speed and judgment to respond to the war situation.

Game scale:

1 turn = 2 days
1 hex = about 1km
1 unit = army including military commanders (100-150 soldiers)


Number of players = 2
Play time = about 240 minutes

Contents (excluding magazines):

216 pieces (15 mm square)
1 map (A1 size)
1 rule book (12 pages)


(translated and adapted from publisher's website)


Command Magazine Japan #137 issue game

name: Kursk's Southern Front: Prokhorovka 1943
description:
The Battle of Prokhorovka was fought on 12 July 1943 near Prokhorovka, 87 kilometres (54 mi) southeast of Kursk in the Soviet Union, during the Second World War. Taking place on the Eastern Front, the engagement was part of the wider Battle of Kursk, and occurred when the 5th Guards Tank Army of the Soviet Red Army attacked the II SS-Panzer Corps of the German Wehrmacht in one of the largest tank battles in military history.

Can you break through the enemy lines and fight back with the Red Army. Will you lead the Soviet forces to victory by controlling the clash in the last German attack on the Eastern Front?

This game covers the attack of 4th Panzer Army and Army Detachment Kempf on the southern part of the Kursk salient. Units are randomly assigned tank and equipment chits at start. There are also single-use support chits which include fighters, bombers, heavy artillery, smoke, minefields, engineers, and snipers.

Time scale: 1 day per turn
Game period: July 5-14 1943
Unit scale: German divisions to battalions; Soviet corps to regiments
Counters: 198
Map: A2 (42 x 59.4 cm)



Included with Game Journal #63.

name: Cellris
description: Cellris is the official board game of Kiscell Museum (Budapest, Hungary), featuring iconic objects and artworks from the museum's collections on tetris tiles. Players need to create a unique exhibition using these objects in the former Baroque church area of the museum. Before they can be exhibited, chosen collection pieces have to go first to the restoration workshop. Victory points depend on the concept how players select and place artwork tiles on the board. For example, players earn points if they set up different types of objects or if they focus solely on artworks from a certain historical period.
mechanics: Pattern Building, Simultaneous Action Selection, Tile Placement

name: Unreal Estate: Sniper's Tower
description: Unreal Estate: Sniper's Tower is a promotional card for the Unreal Estate base game. Its effect: "Before dealing the Proposal Board, take the cards and draft one secretly. Lay out the Proposal Board with the remaining cards, and continue a normal round from the start player."
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy

name: Pocket Investigations: Apocalypse – Prelude
description:
Pocket Investigations is a series of "escape boxes", i.e. board games that are based on escape games, but playable at home.

Apocalypse: Prelude is the first episode of the series: players receive a black envelope sent by a serial killer called Abaddon, the Angel of Death from the Bible. Inside the box: real objects and documents to help them crack the case.

—description from the publisher

name: Loaded Lemons
description: Try to follow the Lemons as they're swapped. When time's up, guess if your lemon shoots water! Guess right or get soaked! To play, fill all of the lemons with water. All of them can be filled, but only two squirt water. Player puts a Lemon in front of them and chooses an either elephant, horse, dog or rooster sound. The Players listen to the electronic timer and swap positions of any two Lemons when they hear their corresponding animal sound. When time's up, they flip their yes/no chip to guess whether or not their lemon shoots water. If they guess yes, they aim at someone else. If they guess no, they aim at themselves. Players can squeeze the Lemons all at once or take turns. Anyone who guessed right gets a lemon chip and the first to collect three chips wins the game.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Children's Game, Electronic, Humor, Memory, Party Game, Real-time

name: Traveller Customizable Card Game: Supplemental Deck Collector's Edition
description: A 90-card deck that contains new cards as well as additional cards from the ship decks that come only in a single copy.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Science Fiction, Space Exploration

name: La bataille des Alphamons
description:
La bataille des Alphamons is a simple simultaneous action selection game for two to 6 players. This game was designed to teach the alphabetical order to young children.

Start by making an alignment with the small alphabet cards that are numbered 1 to 26. This will be used as a reference: letter a will be the smallest and the z will be the highest card.
Deal 9 cards to each player. They all have a card printed on it. All players choose a card, then reveal them simultaneously. Use the reference cards to check witch card is the highest. The highest card wins the trick and take all the cards.
After 9 rounds, the one who has the most cards wins the game.

Alternate rule for older children:
If all the players are familiar with the alphabetical order, you can play with the following rules:
Each time someone makes a trick, the player that has revealed the lowest card can swap 2 cards in the alphabet.
When you have played all the cards in your hand, take the cards you have won to continue playing.
The game ends when one of the player has no more cards. The player who has the most cards wins the game.

—description from the publisher

name: High Roller
description:
Combines the skill of a card game with the fun of a board game.
The object of the game is to win £100.000. Each player is dealt a hand of 7 cards from a standard set of playing cards.
A player may on his turn pick cards from a face down deck to improve your chances of a bigger payout, or roll the dice and land on spots where he can play runs of cards to gain bigger payouts from the bank. However wild card spaces may pay out or may hinder some or all the players
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Push Your Luck, Set Collection

description:
1833 is a card game where the objective is to establish the most valuable railroad network by creating routes between various North American cities of the 19th Century. Players take turns drawing cards and building their railroad connections. Players' resources are limited by number of cards he may hold in his hand, but may be increased by building increasing levels of routes. Route levels (size) are determined by the type of locomotive used for that route. Stockpiling resources (cards) is tricky and dangerous because getting rid of unwanted cards is not trivial. Players may also collect corporation cards which increase the value of the player's routes connected to that corporation's home city. Holding corporation cards count against a player's hand limit; representing the built-in cost of that corporation card. Private company cards (representing privately held railroads) may be used to connect otherwise unconnected cities, but at a cost to the value of the route for which they are used.

—description from the publisher
categories: Card Game, Print & Play, Trains, Transportation
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Open Drafting

name: Pub Battles: Waterloo
description:
Waterloo is a Military Strategy Board Game where Allied players attempt to stop Napoleon in his final battle at Waterloo.

The British under Wellington are outnumbered but they hold good terrain and Prussian reinforcements are constantly streaming into the battle. The French must strike quickly and shatter Wellington before the growing Allied numbers become overwhelming.

name: Total Monstrosities the Card Game: Original Orange
description:
"Total Monstrosities the Card Game - Original Orange" is a game for 1 – 6 players that takes roughly 20 minutes.

The aim of the game is to win 10 Totalmon Cards before your opponents. You win Totalmon cards by having the strongest overall Totalmon at the end of a round. Use Buff and Support Cards to raise your total, or better yet, Mutate your Totalmon into stronger Totalmon to gain the edge.

—description from the publisher

name: Mortain Aug44:  Old Hickory vs. the SS
description:
My devilish little print-and-play regimental/kampfgruppe level game about the desperate German counterattack in southern Normandy - "Normandy's Switzerland" - west toward Avranches and the sea against U.S. 1st Army units, to cut off our (especially Patton's 3rd Army's) breakout into all France. 18 8-hour turns, 7-12Aug44. 23 U.S. (eventually) + 4 tac air vs. 12 or 13 German units. 1 mile/1.6 kilometers per hex and pro-defense combat results, because of the dense, compartmentalizing terrain, which was still bocage as well. Includes divisional and corps artillery and Allied fighterbomber/Jaegerbomber/"Jabo" airpower. There is the 50% possibility of German General der Panzertruppen Gerhard Graf von Schwerin's historical (patriotic) anti-Hitler treachery, which held back 116. PzDiv in the north for 48 crucial hours and profoundly crippled Fall (Operation) Luettich.

Allied player must choose to exit units in the south for victory points or use them instead to stop the German schwerpunkten (from advancing and getting victory points). This is a tight, nerve-wracking game requiring both players to claw for every victory point.

If (von Schwerin has been relieved/arrested and) 116. PzDiv is unleashed, the U.S. player must patiently and enduringly play the long game to wear down German units and catch up by then eliminating them.

—description from the designer
categories: Print & Play, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Network and Route Building, Push Your Luck, Simulation

name: 18Oki
description: One of the 18xx games set in Japan, this one with a historically accurate map based on the island of Okinawa. Shorter play than most 18xx games.
mechanics: Network and Route Building, Pick-up and Deliver, Stock Holding

name: Hail Caesar: Shield Wall
description:
A notoriously unstable and rebellious member of the Roman Empire, Britannia was thrown into bloody conflict as the Western Roman Empire began to crumble. Axe, spear and sword became the dominant currency for those vying for control of the kingdoms.

Shield Wall is a supplement for Hail Caesar which introduces the main battles, armies and personalities of the Dark Ages in the British Isles from around 400AD up to 1000AD.

In addition to the traditional Hail Caesar massed battles the supplement introduces rules for smaller scale engagements between warbands as reflects much of this period. Shield Wall also contains campaign rules and several linked scenarios ­– from Badon Hill to Brunaburh.

The army lists are included for Limitanei, early and late Saxons, Romano-British, Welsh-Cymru, Irish, Picts, Gaels, Vikings and Irish-Norse.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Medieval, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Kingdom of Fools
description:
This game uses the same cards as Marionette Kingdom but is only for 3 players while Marionette Kingdom is for 2 to 3 players.

One player distributes cards in a similar vain as in One Night Werewolf. The other players can only look at their cards, but can exchange their card with an (unknown) card from another player or a card that has been set aside.

Then cards are resolved, giving victory points or allowing to build buildings.

name: Smoke eleQtro plus
description:
Smoke eleQtro plus is a game based on cigarettes.

Players compete for how many cigarettes they can smoke before dying from blackened lungs from both mainstream smoke and secondhand smoke.

"Mainstream smoke" is smoke directly entering the lungs. The lungs of smokers are black. On the other hand, "secondhand smoke" is the smoke emitted by smokers that affects people in the area. It is also called "passive smoking".

Basic Flow of Game
Each player puts up to two cards from a hand of three to the table.

Only those with the largest number of cigarettes on the card will succeed in smoking.

At that time, the lung will become black as many as the number of lung markers on smoking cigarettes. If there is a secondhand smoke on that card, other players who fail to smoke will also receive a lung marker. Even though they were not able to smoke, the lungs slowly become black and bring everyone closer to death.

When only one person is still alive, the game ends and the player who smoked the most cigarettes will win.

name: What in the Wild
description:
What in the Wild is a game system consisting of a deck of 120 cards and rules for 5 different games. Cards contain plant and animal species and the food, water, shelter, and space they need to survive. Much as with wildlife conservation in the real world, the games of What in the Wild focus on cooperation, collaboration, or side by side competition rather than head to head competition. Each game was designed with children and families in mind, and most have variants that let you ramp up the challenge as players get older and are looking for more strategic gameplay.

• Match It! A memory game where you explore the different types of habitat elements and which species use them.
• Connect It! A cooperative game of map building to construct a resilient ecosystem before time runs out.
• Slap It! A fast paced race to assemble habitat for as many species as you can.
• Group It! A push your luck set collection game.
• Build It! A collaborative game of habitat creation.

What in the Wild was designed to complement the Michigan Department of Natural Resources Wildlife Division’s “Go Wild for Michigan’s Wildlife” curriculum for kindergarten through 5th grade. A core element of the curriculum is introducing students to common wildlife species they may encounter and increasing their understanding and appreciation of these animals. This forms the heart of What in the Wild, and its games put their primary focus on fun, engagement, interaction, humor, and challenge. In a classroom setting, it’s a tool for teachers to use to extend student understanding of course content. For a family, the emphasis is on providing fun games that the youngest and oldest members can enjoy together.

description from designer
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Educational, Environmental, Memory
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Hand Management, Memory, Set Collection, Simultaneous Action Selection, Tile Placement
publishers: Michigan Department of Natural Resources, Wildlife Division

name: Transformers Trading Card Game: Convention Edition
description:
The Transformers Trading Card Game is a battling card game designed for two players. Players build a team of Transformers character cards and power them up with a customizable deck of battle cards. Transformers character cards are twice the size of standard playing cards; they can be flipped from bot mode to alt mode and back, and they feature premium printing treatment on one of their sides. The deck of battle cards features Action and Upgrade cards to enhance Transformers character cards.

The Transformers Trading Card Game – Convention Edition serves as an introduction to the game before it's officially released, with these preview cards being distributed at conventions such as Comic-Con International 2018 and Gen Con 2018. This pack contains two Transformers character cards (Cliffjumper – Renegade Warrior and Slipstream – Strategic Seeker) and two battle cards (All-Out Attack and Tandem Targeting System) not available in the Autobots Starter Set or Booster Packs.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fighting

name: Con Red Flags: An Exclusive Expansion to Red Flags
description: Con Red Flags: An Exclusive Expansion to Red Flags is a convention-themed expansion for Red Flags that will be available for purchase solely at conventions starting with Comic-Con International in July 2018.

name: Timestamp
description:
Time travel is an unpredictable and unforgiving science. One wrong move can have catastrophic effects, potentially tearing apart the very fabric of the universe. To prevent such accidents, the secrets of time travel have been hidden in clues spread across the world by some mysterious entity. Your team of scientists is on the brink of unlocking these clues. With a nearly functional device, you prepare to embark on humanity's greatest journey. However you are not the only team to do so...

Timestamp is an episodic adventure game in which two players face off to unlock the mysteries of time travel for the human race. Each postcard installment takes players to new times and locations with unique challenges and goals. Every game will be different as players manage their teams of scientists and resources to perform one of the four actions unique to each card. The first player to meet the scenarios goal wins. Follow the clues, master your device, and unlock time itself!

—description from the publisher


A mysterious device has the potential to change the future. And the past. Across 12 episodes by 4 designers, you will unlock the mysteries of time travel, change history, and hopefully save the future.

Each episode brings a new twist on a central mechanism, as 2 teams of scientists compete to learn more about the device, research events on the timeline, and hunt for key components that will allow them mastery over time. Each episode occurs in a different time and place, from Elizabethan England to earth’s Lunar Colony, so you never know exactly where you’ll end up next.

TimeStamp is the 2018 Board Game of the Month postcard from Button Shy, with each month bringing a new episode, which can be played independently.

—description from the designer


Episodes:

01 – 2020: Santa Colina (Prologue)
02 – 1955: Santa Colina
03 – 2020: Undisclosed location, UT
04 – 1912: Southampton
05 – 2076: Moon Base Adam
06 – 2009: Cambridge
07 – 1888: Range Creek, UT
08 – ????: Middle of Nowhen
09 – 1593: Cambridge
10 – 1947: Roswell, NM
11 – 2045: Geneva
12 – 2020: Santa Colina (End)

name: They Shall Not Pass: Bavarians at the Gates
description:
This is the first of the Avalanche Press Golden Journal supplements. It contains 40 additional counters as well as scenarios and variants for several games:

Scenarios:

They Shall Not Pass: Bavarians at the Gates
They Shall Not Pass: Onlar Kacis Degil mi

Variants:

They Shall Not Pass: Zeppelins Over Verdun
Red Vengeance: Designer Variants
Red Vengeance: While Poles Yet Live
Alsace 1945: Air Pollution

—user summary
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Wargame, World War II

name: Soldier Kings: Most Serene Empire
description:
This is the third of the Avalanche Press Golden Journal supplements. It contains 28 additional counters with a page size color map with rules for variants of two games:

Soldier Kings: Most Serene Empire
Map and additional counters. Adds Venice as a major power to the games. Can replace Holland in a seven- or eight-player game or be played as a ninth power in a nine-player game.

Red Vengeance: The Curse of Turan
Adds units to enlarge and strengthen the Hungarian Armies. This serves to represent "what might have been".
categories: Age of Reason, Expansion for Base-game, Wargame
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Variable Player Powers
